The National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) is a feature-based database that interconnects and uniquely identifies the stream segments or reaches that make up the nation's surface water drainage system. NHD data was originally developed at 1:100,000-scale and exists at that scale for the whole country. This high-resolution NHD, generally developed at 1:24,000/1:12,000 scale, adds detail to the original 1:100,000-scale NHD. (Data for Alaska, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands was developed at high-resolution, not 1:100,000 scale.) Local resolution NHD is being developed where partners and data exist. The NHD contains reach codes for networked features, flow direction, names, and centerline representations for areal water bodies. Reaches are also defined on waterbodies and the approximate shorelines of the Great Lakes, the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and the Gulf of Mexico. The NHD also incorporates the National Spatial Data Infrastructure framework criteria established by the Federal Geographic Data Committee.   The NHD Flowline data sets used included 1) the NHD_West_Slope data set which included line data from Oregon, Washington and Idaho; and 2) the NHD_CA data set which included line data from California. The data setw were clipped to represent the geographic extent of the final designation of critical habitat for eulachon. The NHD lines were also slightly modified to conform to changes in the sleceted rivers that have occurred since the NHD data sets were created.  </supplinf></descript><citation><citeinfo><origin>Marc Romano, National Marine Fisheries Service</origin><pubdate>April 6, 2012</pubdate><title>Eulachon Final Critical Habitat</title><ftname Sync="TRUE">Final_Eulachon_Critical_Habitat</ftname><geoform was created from a prexisting data set called the NHD Flowline, created by the U.S. Geological Survey, Reston VA. The National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) is a feature-based database that interconnects and uniquely identifies the stream segments or reaches that make up the nation's surface water drainage system. NHD data was originally developed at 1:100,000-scale and exists at that scale for the whole country. This high-resolution NHD, generally developed at 1:24,000/1:12,000 scale, adds detail to the original 1:100,000-scale NHD. (Data for Alaska, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands was developed at high-resolution, not 1:100,000 scale.) Local resolution NHD is being developed where partners and data exist. The NHD contains reach codes for networked features, flow direction, names, and centerline representations for areal water bodies. Reaches are also defined on waterbodies and the approximate shorelines of the Great Lakes, the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and the Gulf of Mexico. The NHD also incorporates the National Spatial Data Infrastructure framework criteria established by the Federal Geographic Data Committee.   The NHD Flowline data sets used included 1) the NHD_West_Slope data set which included line data from Oregon, Washington and Idaho; and 2) the NHD_CA data set which included line data from California. The data setw were clipped to represent the geographic extent of the final designation of critical habitat for eulachon. The NHD lines were also slightly modified to conform to changes in the sleceted rivers that have occurred since the NHD data sets were created.  </dsoverv></overview></eainfo><mdDateSt
